p01: Learn how to easily set up an X1 blockchain validator in this simple step-by-step guide—it's so easy that even Homer Simpson managed it!

step1.title: Step 1: Rent a Server
step1.p01: To set up your X1 Validator, you need a server, which you can rent from various providers on a monthly basis. If you already have a server that meets the minimum requirements (see image), you can skip this step. Otherwise, continue with <telegramLink>Rent Server</telegramLink>.

step2.title: Step 2: Connect to Server
step2.p01: Connect to your server. If you are using Windows as your operating system, you will need the PuTTY program to access the server. If you already have PuTTY, you can skip this step. Otherwise, continue with <telegramLink>Ubuntu (PuTTY)</telegramLink>.

step3.p13: 1. If you lose access to the server, you will also lose access to your wallet. To avoid this, make a note of the seed phrase for each individual wallet – four in total. If, like me, you only see two wallets in your terminal window, simply scroll up. You do not need to write down the “pubkey” address manually, as you can find it in the X1 Console at any time.
step3.p14: 2. Once you have noted down your seed phrases for the respective wallets, your “id” wallet needs XNT. To do this, go to the <telegramLink>Faucet Website</telegramLink>.
step3.p15: If the faucet is empty, you still have the option of asking the <telegramLink>Validator Telegram Group</telegramLink> to send you XNT. Simply write your pubkey/address from the ID wallet in the chat and ask for XNT.
step3.p16: Alternatively, you can also contact me directly in the Telegram group <telegramLink>X1BlockchainGuide</telegramLink>. Press the Enter key and continue with the installation. You can also complete the installation without XNT.

step4.title: Step 4: Delinquent status
step4.p01: If you skipped the step with the XNT, take a look at the next image. If your status is “Delinquent”, your ID Wallet must have at least 1 XNT.
